awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Predator-driven evolution of shell structure at different scales during the Mesozoic Marine Revolution: An interdisciplinary experimental investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

The world’s marine ecosystems are currently experiencing many pressures from human activities. For example, warming global temperatures have changed ocean chemistry in ways that influence the strength of many mollusk shells. These shells are key to the survival of organisms like clams and snails, which use their shells as a defense mechanism against shell-crushing predators like fishes and crabs. In addition to climate change, marine ecosystems have been stressed by overfishing, where the preferential removal of predators has cascading effects on their prey. One way to anticipate the long-term impacts of climate change and changing marine predatory regimes is to study similar events from the past. During the Mesozoic (250-65 million years ago) the world was experiencing extremely warm, greenhouse conditions. Additionally, shell-crushing predators became increasingly powerful, putting increased selective pressures on their prey. This study will use physical and numerical experiments to analyze how increasing temperatures and changes in predation pressures impacted the shells of marine snails during the Mesozoic to inform modern ecosystem conservation efforts. Moreover, by studying the exceptional strength of snail shells, this research will have applications for the bio-inspired design of crack resistant materials. The use of physical models for this research will also enable the creation of accessible, interactive 3D printed museum displays applicable to educational modules across disciplines including paleontology, conservation, and biomechanics. While conducting this interdisciplinary research, Dr. Johnson will mentor underrepresented and underserved students from high school and undergraduate programs, who are interested in biology, ecology, paleontology, biomechanics, or related STEM fields.

Changes in defensive snail shell morphologies are central to the Mesozoic Marine Revolution hypothesis—an event of predator-driven evolution during a period of greenhouse conditions. However, we lack rigorous quantitative metrics by which to evaluate predator-driven evolution throughout this time. This project will use an innovative approach to quantify prey response by experimentally determining how gastropod shells would evolve in a model system driven primarily by shell-crushing predators. This will be accomplished using a novel cross-scale approach, applying finite element analysis modeling incorporating both shell macrostructure (shape) and microstructural material properties, and validating the analysis with modern and fossil shells. This research will generate a theoretical morphospace which quantifies the defensive capabilities of a range of shell shapes and microstructural combinations. The model framework generated from this research will have fundamental applications for studies of predator-prey driven evolution, conservation paleobiology, and materials science. The world’s oceans are currently facing intense anthropogenic pressures from overfishing and a rapidly changing climate, which are highly likely to negatively impact mollusks and fishes. This study will inform conservation efforts which extend beyond the temporal scale of modern ecological studies. Furthermore, the results of this study will have implications for the development of stronger, crack resistant bioinspired materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We used multiple approaches to examine how predators influence the evolution of their prey and vice versa. Working with paleontologists and engineers, I created a series of experimental approaches to analyze how mollusk shells evolved as armor against shell-crushing predators, like crabs. These studies addressed the fossil record and modern ecological interactions using mechanical, morphometric, and live feeding approaches to test predator-prey interactions.

We conducted live feeding experiments with two crab species, Calappa flammea and Menippe mercenaria, to compare their shell-breaking abilities. Calappa have a unique tubercle on their right claw which allows them to peel the shells of gastropods. Menippe rely on crushing gastropod shells whole. By analyzing how long it took crabs of both species to induce breakage in the shells of gastropods and bivalves, we found that the tubercle likely represents an evolutionary innovation, rather than a specialization (as previously thought). This innovation allows Calappa to break into gastropod shells faster than their competitors and helps them to break large shells that whole-body crushers would struggle with due to gape limitation. We also documented the ability of Calappa to manipulate left-coiling shells, which were previously thought to be confounding to these right-handed predators. The tubercle is an innovation, rather than a specialization, because it expands the range of prey resources for Calappa without restricting their consumption of other prey (like bivalves). Our observations also helped us design an apparatus for mechanical tests that allow us to compare the work done to break shells using these two different predation strategies.

We also studied the geometry of predation traces left by crabs on their gastropod prey with geometric morphometric analyses of breakage shapes on shells used during live feeding trials. We found that similar traces can be found in the fossil record, allowing us to identify ancient predator-prey interactions. Although shape alone did not always indicate a difference between crushing (Menippe) and peeling (Calappa) predators, the degree to which the trace coiled along the shell was informative.

We also experimentally created steinkerns (infills of shells) using modern gastropods, to study the fidelity of internal molds to the geometry of external shells. Gastropods have an well-preserved, geographically expansive, and geologically continuous fossil record. However, specimens preserved as internal molds are largely understudied, in part due to uncertainty about assigning taxonomic identification based on internal morphology (where external morphology is typically used). Our work quantified differences in steinkern and external shell geometric fidelity, demonstrating that some taxa are much more likely to be misidentified than others. This data will help future researchers quantify potential error in studies (e.g., ecological composition) that rely on samples where steinkerns are prevalent.

We also studied how the geometry of gastropod shells has changed during key ecological intervals. Shell shape is indicative of both how an organism lives and how well the shell acts as armor. We created, to our knowledge, the first fossil data for gastropod shell shape using David Raup's famous theoretical morphospace by conducting morphometrics on gastropod samples from the Devonian, Cretaceous, and Pliocene

Broader Impacts:

I worked with Yale Peabody Museum's EVOLUTIONS after school program for high school students from underprivileged and underserved backgrounds. I thought hands on lessons using fossil materials to educate the students about predator-prey interactions over deep time. They used information from my presentation to examine fossils and determine what type of predator-prey interactions they were observing. I used this module to teach them how paleoecology is used for modern conservation. With an undergraduate mentee, I also conducted an activity using artificial steinkerns from our research to have students think about modes of fossil preservation and to learn how to think about the bias and limitations of the fossil record.

Together with an engineering mentee, I also used my research to develop a physical theoretical morphospace model for educational purposes. The model will help students understand concepts spanning evolution, paleontology, mathematics, and engineering. We constructed this module using mathematically generated, 3D printed theoretical mollusk shell shapes. We are now working to quantify the efficacy of this module as a teaching tool.

Throughout this project, I mentored students at all academic levels who came from underrepresented and underserved backgrounds. This included ten undergraduates from three universities and two local high school students. My students all got hands on research experience and academic mentorship. Two of my undergraduate mentees, both women of color, have received NSF graduate research fellowships to pursue their PhDs. One is a coauthor on an accepted publication and the other is a coauthor on a submitted manuscript from our research. Two other students attended a national conference to present the research they conducted with me. Another has submitted an abstract to present her work with me at a conference this year.
